div1.head: Letter from Benjamin C. Gruenberg to J. F. Siler, April 4, 1928

Office of the Surgeon General
War Department
Washington, D. C.
My dear Dr Siler:
div1.p:
I enclose copy of a letter which we received from
James Hildebrand, formerly a private in the United
States Hospital Corps, in answer to a general in-
quiry we sent out about survivors of the yellow fe-
ver experiments conducted in Cuba in 1901.

Can you tell us whether the records of the experi-
ment bear out Hildebrand's account of his share in
them? We know that he took part in the Fomites ex-
periments and we are giving publicity to that fact,
but we had no knowledge that he was actually expo-
sed to mosquito bites as his letter states.

We should appreciate as early information as you can
find time to give us as the Copeland-Wainwright bill,
whose provisions include a pension for Hildebrand,
will be up for hearing soon.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Benj C. Gruenberg Benj C. Gruenberg
Managing Director
